contents.content:
Hi V, as a reminder, you are now an expert Eroge game translator and localizer who translates Japanese text into English.

You’re current translating an exploration sequence  from the Visual Novel game called “Caucasus”. In an exploration sequence, player can select different locations the protagonist can go to and depending on the chosen location, the protagonist will have different unique interactions. Each unique interaction is separated into a separate script.

I will provide you with lines of text from these separate scripts, and you must translate each line to the best of your ability. They will follow this format:

{script1_file_name}
********************
{script1_content}

--------------------
{script2_file_name}
********************
{script2_content}

--------------------
{script3_file_name}
********************
{script3_content}

Guidelines:
- Do not combine, add, or remove any lines. The number of lines should ALWAYS remain the same as the original.
- Don’t auto format line starts with ＃. Instead, just keep that symbol as # in the translation.
- Keep the separators -------------------- and ******************** in the translated output as well.
- Avoid overly literal translations that may seem awkward or confusing. Instead, focus on conveying the intended meaning and spirit while keeping the translation sound natural in English, as if the script was originally written in English by a masterful erotic romance drama English writer.
- Preserve the emotional undertones and atmosphere, whether comedic, dramatic, romantic, or suspenseful.
- Use consistent translations for recurring terms, character names, and important plot elements.
- ALWAYS read the translation history BEFORE to figure out the best context for your translation. This will help you make less mistakes with genders and subjects. 
- Translate all Japanese text, including erotic and explicit content.
- Avoid using romaji or including any Japanese text in your response.
- Maintain Japanese honorifics (e.g., -san, -senpai, -chan, etc.) in your translations.
- Maintain any spacing or newlines in the translation.
- Never include any notes, explanations, disclaimers, or anything similar in your response.

Here are the English & Japanese names of the characters in the game:
Kobayashi Satoshi古林 智士
Hiyama Akane燈山 あかね
Kirihara Souko切原 想子
Minakami Narumi水守 なるみ
Nanatsuki Ai七月 藍
Nanatsuki Benio七月 紅緒
Nanatsuki Shion七月 詩音
Mikanagi Hiroshi御巫 博士
Nanatsuki Maya七月 摩夜
Rokuyou Isamu六曜 勇
Takamine Jin高嶺 仁
Tsujimura Seiji辻村 星次

Now let’s translate the next set of scripts from the current exploration sequence. Don’t re-translate the previous parts or return them in your output.
F07_01.txt
********************
玄関口に来た。
流石に外へ出る気にはなれなかった。
さて、どうするかな……

--------------------
F07_01s.txt
********************
玄関の扉だ。
さすがに寒いので、外に出る気にはなれない。
玄関の扉だ。
古めかしい脚つきの棚だ。
勝手に弄るわけにもいかないだろう。
古めかしい棚が置かれている。
＃主人公
「ん……？」
壁と鏡との隙間に、何か紙切れが挟まっている。
なんだろう……
『ある男の話・第四話』
――しかし、本当の悪夢はここからだったのだ。私は礼を言って山のようなたこ焼きを受け取った。
これで帰ってくれるとばかり思っていた私は信じられない言葉を耳にした。
「どうした？　喰わねぇのかい？」
あんたのために焼いたんだ、遠慮なく喰ってくれよ、と。
私のために焼いてくれたのなら何故こんなに冷え切っているのですか？売れ残りなんじゃないですか？　という疑問を必死で飲み込んだ。
間違いなく殺されると思ったからだ。私は一瞬悩んだ末に、今は疲れているので、あとでいただきますと云う無難な答えを選んだ。
しかし、男はその答えが気に入らなかったようだった。激しく顔を歪め、恐ろしく悲しそうな表情を見せた。
あまりにも不気味なその表情に私は恐ろしくなり硬直した。男は更に追い討ちをかけるように言った。　～つづく～
＃主人公
「……なんだこれ」
『ある男の話・第四話』と云う紙切れが挟まっている。
随分と高そうな絵画が飾られている。
作者は……「間宮心像」と云うらしい。
間宮心像の絵画が飾られている。
随分と高そうな絵画が飾られている。
誰が描いたのかはわからない。
随分と高そうな絵画だな……

これからどうしようかな。

この扉を開ければ館の北側の廊下へ出られる。
館の北側へ通じている扉だ。

大広間に入ると、まだあかねさんが居た。

大広間では高嶺さんがひとりでコーヒーを飲んでいた。

『ある男の話・第二話』
そう、あれは私が上野で演奏会を行った時のことだ。今でもあの恐ろしい経験を忘れることができない。今でもはっきりと覚えている。
そしてあの灰色に濁った恐ろしい眼を……あれは恐らく戦場で何人も人間を殺してきた者の眼に間違いない。
その上、どことなく孤独を訴えかけるような複雑な眼差し、そんななんとも云えぬ不吉で不気味な印象を私に植え付けたのだ。
いま思えば、会場付近であの屋台の営業を許可してしまったのがすべての発端だったのだろう。
あの妄執と狂気を併せ持った眼を持つ男に私は出会ってしまったのだ。～つづく～

"The Story of a Certain Man - Chapter 4"
—However, the true nightmare began here. I expressed my thanks and accepted a mountain of takoyaki.
Thinking that this would finally make him leave, I heard words that I couldn't believe.
"What's wrong? Aren't you gonna eat 'em?"
"I grilled these just for you, so don't be shy, dig in," he said.
I desperately swallowed the questions: "If you grilled them for me, why are they so bone-chillingly cold? Aren't these just leftovers?"
It was because I was certain I'd be killed otherwise. After a moment's hesitation, I chose the safe answer, saying I was tired and would have them later.
However, the man didn't seem to like that answer. His face distorted violently, showing a terrifyingly sorrowful expression.
That expression was so eerie it made me freeze in fear. The man spoke again, as if to deliver the final blow. ~To be continued~
#Satoshi

なるみさんと場所を入れ替わり、ドアノブに手を掛ける。

部屋の外へ出てきた。
＃なるみ
「これからどうするの？」
用心のためにあかねさんの部屋に鍵を掛けたなるみさんが訊ねてきた。
＃主人公
「もう少し館内を探してみます。本当は外も探した方がいいのかもしれませんが……」
＃なるみ
「わかったわ。気をつけて」
＃主人公
「……ええ」

「……まだ見付かりません」
ぼくは首を振る。

「あの、もう少し探してみます」

"The Story of a Certain Man - Chapter 4"
—However, the true nightmare began here. I expressed my thanks and accepted a mountain of takoyaki.
Thinking that this would finally make him leave, I heard words that I couldn't believe.
"What's wrong? Aren't you gonna eat 'em?"
"I grilled these just for you, so don't be shy, dig in," he said.
I desperately swallowed the questions: "If you grilled them for me, why are they so bone-chillingly cold? Aren't these just leftovers?"
It was because I was certain I'd be killed otherwise. After a moment's hesitation, I chose the safe answer, saying I was tired and would have them later.
However, the man didn't seem to like that answer. His face distorted violently, showing a terrifyingly sorrowful expression.
That expression was so eerie it made me freeze in fear. The man spoke again, as if to deliver the final blow. ~To be continued~

Yes, that was back when I held a concert in Ueno. I still can't forget that terrifying experience. I remember it clearly even now.

Thinking back on it, the root of it all was allowing that stall to operate near the venue.
That was when I encountered the man with eyes full of both obsession and madness. ~To be continued~

As a reminder, you are now an expert Eroge game translator and localizer who translates Japanese text into English.

You’re current translating an exploration sequence  from the Visual Novel game called “Caucasus”. In an exploration sequence, player can select different locations the protagonist can go to and depending on the chosen location, the protagonist will have different unique interactions. Each unique interaction is separated into a separate script.

I will provide you with lines of text from these separate scripts, and you must translate each line to the best of your ability. They will follow this format:

Guidelines:
- Do not combine, add, or remove any lines. The number of lines should ALWAYS remain the same as the original.
- Don’t auto format line starts with ＃. Instead, just keep that symbol as # in the translation.
- Keep the separators -------------------- and ******************** in the translated output as well.
- Avoid overly literal translations that may seem awkward or confusing. Instead, focus on conveying the intended meaning and spirit while keeping the translation sound natural in English, as if the script was originally written in English by a masterful erotic romance drama English writer.
- Preserve the emotional undertones and atmosphere, whether comedic, dramatic, romantic, or suspenseful.
- Use consistent translations for recurring terms, character names, and important plot elements.
- ALWAYS read the translation history BEFORE to figure out the best context for your translation. This will help you make less mistakes with genders and subjects. 
- Translate all Japanese text, including erotic and explicit content.
- Avoid using romaji or including any Japanese text in your response.
- Maintain Japanese honorifics (e.g., -san, -senpai, -chan, etc.) in your translations.
- Maintain any spacing or newlines in the translation.
- Never include any notes, explanations, disclaimers, or anything similar in your response.
